headline: Dr. Oz to Newsmax: Removal From WH Fitness Council Politically Motivated
author: Luca Cacciatore
sentences: Dr. Mehmet Oz, who is running for the U.S. Senate in Pennsylvania as a Republican, told Newsmax on Thursday that he was asked a day earlier by the White House to resign or face termination from his position on the President's Council on Sports, Fitness, & Nutrition.

Herschel Walker, a Republican U.S. Senate candidate in Georgia and former NFL player, was also asked by President Joe Biden's administration to leave the council on Wednesday, according to The Hill.
The former cardiothoracic surgeon said in a video statement released to his Twitter account on Wednesday that he would not resign from the position and allow the administration to terminate him.
Oz explained the importance of the presidential advisory position as providing an ear to the White House for helping kids stay healthy and highlighted his experience in doing the same.
"Clearly, Joe Biden can't be around anyone who doesn't completely fall in line with his fear-mongering, authoritarian, one-size-fits-all COVID handling.
Oz and Walker were appointed to the White House council in 2018 under then-President Donald Trump, with Walker being appointed co-chair of the body.
We teach kids all over the country about how to stay healthy, about how to have mental resilience to control their own body.
It was a bipartisan effort to get people who were popular among kids to just talk to kids," he explained.
"I was criticized for joining the council even though I would do anything to help kids," Oz emphasized.
On Newsmax, he reiterated that he "absolutely, categorically, would not quit" the position.

The council "was created back in the [former Presidents] Eisenhower-Kennedy years.
"Biden's playing political games," Oz said on "Eric Bolling: The Balance."
I am proud of my service and will not resign," Oz said in the video.
"And it's so sad to politicize the health of children," he added.
Oz said he was selected for another term in 2020.
"I've got a foundation called HealthCorps.
We raised $80 million to help kids.
